flow.context: Natalia Levy is a Housing Liaison at Poppy Rentals (Stay Poppy) in Palm Springs — she coordinates housing logistics and surfaced as the operational contact for a collegiate baseball league partnership, making her the most directly reachable person at Poppy with a verified phone and email. She's likely not the decision-maker for inspection software, but she can route you to Kelly McLean Lewin (COO/CEO) or the property management team (Angela Swan, Kelly Lipscomb). Poppy manages 130+ vacation rental homes, rebranded from McLean Company (est. 1984), runs on Streamline PMS, and has no confirmed inspection platform — real gap for RapidEye. Your play: build rapport, see if she touches turnovers, and get routed to the right ops leader. SoCal connection — you grew up in La Cañada, she's in Palm Springs.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Natalia — I've been talking with a few vacation rental companies out in the Palm Springs area. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: Relaxed, casual tone. Feet on the desk. Don't rush — let the question hang after you ask it.

branches.label: This isn't Natalia / someone else picks up

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone in your world. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Rare but roll with it. Let her talk. Match her energy and transition naturally into discovery.

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD OF YOU
heard_no.say: Oh, I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call —
heard_no.note: Slight laugh, self-deprecating. Then move right into the pain trigger. If she cuts you off or sounds annoyed, pivot to permission fallback instead.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow or later this week?
bad_timing.note: Don't push. Just get a specific callback window if you can. Note the day and time she gives you.

branches.label: She gives a day or time

gatekeeper.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper.say: Oh hey — could you get me through to Natalia? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: This number (760-699-2229) is also Poppy's main line, so you'll likely get a front desk. Don't explain anything. First name only. Casual.

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — Natalia Levy. I work with a few other vacation rental managers in Palm Springs. Would you mind letting her know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Just enough to sound legitimate. Still no pitch. If they push for more, go to social proof.

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally understand. We help a couple other property management companies in the desert with their inspection workflows — I sent her a note, would you mind giving her a heads up that I called? Sam Parks, RapidEye.
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Leave your name clearly. If they offer voicemail, take it and keep it under 20 seconds. If they won't budge, fish for who the right person actually is.

branches.label: They transfer you or take a message

gatekeeper_blocked.label: GATEKEEPER — BLOCKED
gatekeeper_blocked.say: Appreciate that — and just so I'm calling the right person next time, would it be Kelly or one of the property managers who handles the inspection side of things?
gatekeeper_blocked.note: Fish for the right name. You're hoping to hear Kelly McLean Lewin (COO), Angela Swan, or Kelly Lipscomb (Property Managers). Write down whatever they give you.

branches.label: They give you a name or suggestion

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: Yeah so I've been talking to a few vacation rental companies around the same size as Poppy — you know, 130-plus homes — and the thing I keep hearing is after every turnover, somebody's gotta flip through all these photos trying to catch whether a guest messed something up. And when you're in peak season and turnovers are back to back, stuff just slips through. A guest checks in, there's a stain on the couch nobody flagged, and now you've got a complaint and an owner calling. We built a tool that looks at the turnover photos your team's already taking and flags issues automatically — no extra steps. I'm honestly not sure if that falls in your world or someone else's at Poppy — does any of that sound familiar?
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after the question. Let her react. The last line is critical — it gives her a graceful out to say 'not my area' which opens the referral path. Don't rush past it.

branches.label: 'That's not really my area' / 'You'd need to talk to...'
'We already have a process for that'
'Can you just send me an email?'

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? And you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
permission_fallback.note: Disarming honesty. Most people give you the 30 seconds. If they do, go straight into the pain trigger — don't waste a word.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't interesting?
permission_rejected.note: You're not begging. You're qualifying out. The multiple choice often pulls people back in.

warm_response.label: WARM — DISCOVERY
warm_response.say: Oh interesting — that's exactly what I keep hearing from folks out there. So I can be helpful and not waste your time — what does your day-to-day look like at Poppy? Are you dealing with turnovers and inspections at all, or does that sit with someone else on the team?
warm_response.note: STOP PITCHING. She's warm — ask questions. You're figuring out if she's a user, a buyer, or a bridge to the buyer. If she mentions Kelly, Angela, or any property manager by name, that's gold.

branches.label: 'I handle some of that / I coordinate the homes'
'That's the property managers / Kelly / someone else'
'I'm not sure / it's kind of everyone'

she_is_involved.label: SHE TOUCHES TURNOVERS
she_is_involved.say: Got it — so when a guest checks out and your cleaning crew goes in, are they taking photos right now? And who's actually reviewing those before the next guest arrives?
she_is_involved.note: Dig into the workflow. You want to know: who takes photos, who reviews them, what tool they use (they're on Streamline but may not have a dedicated ops platform), and where things fall through the cracks.

deeper_discovery.label: DIG INTO THE PAIN
deeper_discovery.say: Makes sense. And when something does get missed — like damage that shows up after the next guest checks in — what happens? Does that come out of Poppy's pocket, or is there a charge-back process with the guest?
deeper_discovery.note: You're building the cost-of-the-problem case. This tells you how mature their damage recovery process is. If she mentions Streamline, AppFolio, or any tool — note it for the demo. If she defers to management, pivot to a referral.

branches.label: She's not sure about the financial side

not_her_area.label: NOT HER AREA — PIVOT TO REFERRAL
not_her_area.say: Totally makes sense — that's exactly why I wanted to ask. Who on your team would be the right person for something like this? I know you guys have a pretty big operation over there.
not_her_area.note: Don't push. She's giving you the out — take it gracefully and mine for a name. You're hoping for Kelly McLean Lewin (COO), Angela Swan, or Kelly Lipscomb (Property Managers).

referral_ask.label: FISH FOR THE RIGHT NAME
referral_ask.say: No worries at all. Usually at a company Poppy's size, it'd be someone on the operations side — whoever oversees the property managers or the turnover process. Does that ring a bell for who that might be?
referral_ask.note: Guide her toward the right title without naming names. If she says 'Kelly' that's likely Kelly McLean Lewin, the COO. If she mentions Angela or Kelly Lipscomb, those are Property Managers. Any name is a win.

got_referral.label: GOT A NAME
got_referral.say: Perfect — that's super helpful. And just so I can put something relevant together for them — do you know if they're usually reachable at this number, or is there a better way to get ahold of them?
got_referral.note: You got the name — now try for a direct line or email. Don't push too hard, you already won. Write everything down.

branches.label: 'Just call the main number' / no more info

referral_bridge.label: CLOSE WITH REFERRAL
referral_bridge.say: Really appreciate that, Natalia. I'll reach out to them and mention you pointed me their way — that way it doesn't come totally out of left field. Thanks for taking my call.
referral_bridge.note: Name-drop Natalia when you call the referral — it turns your next cold call into a warm one. Log the referral name, contact details, and anything she said about their process in your CRM immediately.

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it — I should've assumed you'd be all set, otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it more that this isn't a problem you're focused on right now, or is it just that cold calls are the worst?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first — surprise her by not pushing back. The multiple choice softens the rejection and usually gets them talking again.

branches.label: 'I just hate cold calls' / softens a bit
She opens up / asks a question

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with 130-plus homes you'd have to have something in place. Just out of curiosity, is your team pretty happy with how it's working, or is it more that switching anything right now would just be a headache?
objection_have_process.note: Validate them. The split separates 'satisfied' from 'stuck.' If they're stuck, there's an opening. If she mentions a tool by name, note it.

branches.label: She vents about the current process

value_offer.label: VALUE OFFER — SELL THE TEST DRIVE
value_offer.say: Totally respect that. You're probably not buying anything from a cold call today — I wouldn't either. But if nothing else, I could walk you or whoever handles inspections through what a couple other PM companies in the desert are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
value_offer.note: Low pressure. You're selling the meeting as worth their time even if they never buy. If she's clearly not the decision-maker, pivot toward getting the referral name.

branches.label: 'You'd want to talk to [name] about that'

cta_meeting.label: ASK FOR THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Would you be open to hopping on a quick call sometime this week — even just 15 minutes? I can show you what it actually looks like instead of me trying to explain it over a cold call.
cta_meeting.note: Keep it casual. 15 minutes feels low-commitment. If she says she's not the right person for the meeting, pivot to getting the referral for who should be on it.

branches.label: 'I'm not the right person for that'

book_meeting.label: LOCK IN THE TIME
book_meeting.say: Awesome — I've got next Tuesday and Thursday open. Does either of those work for you? Morning or afternoon?
book_meeting.note: Be specific. Don't say 'whenever works.' Pick two days and let her choose. If she wants to loop someone else in, even better — ask who.

branches.label: 'Let me check and get back to you'

meeting_confirmed.label: MEETING BOOKED
meeting_confirmed.say: Perfect — I'll send over a calendar invite right now so it doesn't disappear. Really appreciate you taking my call, Natalia. Talk soon.
meeting_confirmed.note: Send the invite WHILE on the phone. Stop selling. You won. Get off the call.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair — I'll shoot something over. One quick question so it's actually useful and not just another generic pitch — what would be most relevant for me to include?
send_email.note: Get intel on what matters to her or who she'd forward it to. Her email is nlevy@staypoppy.com. If she gives you another name or email, that's a referral in disguise.

branches.label: She gives guidance on what to include

email_question.label: GET THE EMAIL AND CLOSE
email_question.say: Got it — I'll put something together. And if there's someone else on the team I should copy on it, happy to do that. Should I send it to your email, or is there a better one?
email_question.note: If she confirms her email or gives you someone else's, that's gold. Include a specific meeting time suggestion in the email. Follow up within the hour while the call is fresh.

branches.label: She confirms her email or gives another

graceful_exit.label: END CALL
graceful_exit.say: Really appreciate your time, Natalia. If anything comes up, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Have a good one.
graceful_exit.note: Don't burn the bridge. Log everything she told you immediately — names, process details, callback times, email addresses. If she gave you a referral, call that person within the hour while Natalia's name is fresh.
